title: Stocks Edge Lower, Bond Yields Rise After Inflation Data; Inflation accelerated to 7.5% annual rate in January; 10-year Treasury yield rise above 2%
text:
The moves followed new pricing data, showing inflation accelerated to a 7.5% annual rate in January, topping economists' forecasts and December's 7% pace. Bond yields, meanwhile, rose to 2.021% from 1.928% Wednesday, going above 2%for the first time since 2019. The yield on two-year notes, which are particularly sensitive to interest rates, rose to 1.493% from 1.346%.

The data injected fresh uncertainty into a market that had showed some signs of stabilizing: the S&P 500 had risen seven of the past 10 trading days. Money managers say they are bracing for more volatility as investors assess the likelihood of whether the Federal Reserve will have to act more aggressively to tame inflation.

"Speculation regarding the outcome of the next [Fed meeting] will now run rife," said Sandra Holdsworth, head of rates UK at Aegon Asset Management. "With inflation at these levels and still not expected to have peaked, it's hard to argue whether 25 basis points, 50 basis points or even more is the right response from the central bank."

Shares of fast-growing companies were hit hardest. Tech stocks in the S&P 500 fell 0.8%, with software, IT services and semiconductor companies all mostly falling. Qualcomm and Advanced Micro Devices fell more than 2% each, while Apple and Adobe shed 0.8% and 3%, respectively.

Twitter shares rose 0.5% after the social-media company said it had largely dodged the effect of privacy changes hurting Facebook parent Meta Platforms.

Other laggards included PepsiCo, which fell 1% after raising its dividend and setting a $10 billion stock buyback program. The S&P 500's utilities sector fell more than 1%, while the health-care segment shed 0.5%.

Among the bright spots, Walt Disney jumped 4.2% after it reported 11.8 million new subscribers for its Disney+ streaming service in the fourth quarter. Uber Technologies, meanwhile, slipped 2.7% after the ride-hailing firm said quarterly revenue climbed 83%.

Twilio added 9% after the software company said revenue and profits topped analysts' forecasts. Mattel also topped forecasts, sending shares of the toy maker 9% higher.

Overseas stock markets were mixed. The Stoxx Europe 600 was flat as gains for real-estate stocks offset losses for shares of media and financial-service companies.

Siemens rose 6.1% after the German industrial company said rising orders goosed quarterly revenue and profits. Société Générale said profits climbed in the final quarter of 2021, lifting shares 4.7%. Delivery Hero plunged 22% after the German food-delivery firm said it lost money in 2021.

In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 added 0.4% and the Shanghai Composite ticked up 0.2%. In Hong Kong, China Evergrande shares rose 5.4% after reports that the embattled property company plans to restore construction and sales activity, while refraining from a fire sale of its assets.
